definitions.definition: Of, relating to, or located at or near a margin or edge ; also figurative usages of location and margin (edge) .
examples: The marginal area at the edge of the salt-marsh has its own plants.
In recent years there has been an increase in violence against marginal groups.

subdefinitions.definition: Written in the margin of a book .
examples: There were more marginal notes than text.
Monmouthshire is a Welsh county marginal to England.

definitions.definition: Determined by a small margin; having a salient characteristic determined by a small margin.

subdefinitions.definition: Of a value, or having a characteristic that is of a value, that is close to being unacceptable or leading to exclusion from a group or category.
examples: His writing ability was marginal at best.
Having reviewed the test, there are two students below the required standard and three more who are marginal .
The pilots lacked experience flying in marginal weather conditions.
He farmed his marginal land with difficulty.

subdefinitions.definition: Subject to a change in sitting member with only a small change in voting behaviour, this usually being inferred from the small winning margin of the previous election.
examples: In Bristol West, Labour had a majority of only 1,000, so the seat is considered highly marginal this time around.
subdefinitions.label_groups: politics , chiefly UK , Australia , New Zealand , of a constituency

definitions.definition: Pertaining to changes resulting from a unit increase in production or consumption of a good.

main_definition: ( not comparable ) Of, relating to, or located at or near a margin or edge ; also figurative usages of location and margin (edge) .
secondary_definitions: ( comparable ) Determined by a small margin; having a salient characteristic determined by a small margin.
( economics , not comparable ) Pertaining to changes resulting from a unit increase in production or consumption of a good.
